data.text: I've used this app since 2017. I love the free app. the ability to check your scores and little words of encouragement that pop up when you make progress, and emails you get to improve, or look for a new card. I have had several loans thru this app giving recommendations and really love it! I wasn't a fan of the karma drive at first, but it did give me a great score on insurance! I received their Instant Karma feature when it first came out, which was awesome, but it's no longer available.

Similar to others, too many ads. it's clear that the driving purpose of this app is to get you to buy other products. I can easily find information about my credit score and get a loan, but finding information about my budget is gone. The convenience from mint that made it so helpful in budgeting, such as categories, setting goals, etc, are gone. Too bad because I used it for years. Deleting the app and my account and moving on.

One massive ad masquerading as an app. Mint had it's fair share of ads as well, but at least it was useful. Now, I no longer have my home screen widget that I had before, credit cards aren't linking correctly, I can't hide transactions and sub accounts from my net worth calculations, and I get way more spam then I did before. Way to screw up everything you touch, Intuit. All good in search of the all mighty dollar, I guess.

I was forced to switch to this from mint. I can't find where I can view my individual transactions (don't think it exists) and it's more ads than information. I get needing some ads to keep the app free to me, but I feel like I'm giving away personal information for companies to better target me and to get hardly anything in return. The one positive I can see is that I now see two credit scores instead of one. Not that helpful. Very disappointed.

I used to love this app, but it changed way too much. I don't know the score system they used to use because they no longer advertise it, so I assume they changed over to FICO scoring, which takes longer to update. I also noticed that their name changed to Intuit Credit Karma. It's too bad they ruined the app. Love this app! It lets me keep track of my credit score, and It gives me approval odds on credit cards and personal loans recommendations.

When I started using this service,was decent. Keeps avarage track of your credit score, so you have an idea to plan finances accordingly. Now, is not entirely accurate, doesn't matter how good of a score you have. Over time this service has focused on ads and marketing that not necessarily helps the customer, as well there a is a lot of click baiting when it comes to offers, where you apply for any service and it will end up in calls to offer more than needed or creating useless accounts.

I was migrated over from Mint which was good but not great. In comparison Credit Karma is absolute garbage. I can't see bank account transactions anymore. It's hard to navigate to my account information (credit cards, bank accounts, etc.) because they are not in one place. Plus the app is more adds than information. Needs a ton of work to provide relevant information to the user.

I was forced to switch to this app from mint. I used mint for many years and loved the easy convenience of everything being only a click away. Credit karma on the other hand is not intuitive, it's hard to navigate, and it's jam packed with unwanted offers. It does have a few extra features, but it's so much worse of an app than mint! I wish they would give you the option to go back.

Mint alternative? Uh, no. This app is terrible to navigate. The data is buried under so many ads, the menu is not intuitive and there's now way to create your own transaction categories. I wanted the ability to see all of our family accounts in one place, keep an eye on bank balances and transactions. I had certain custom transaction categories for tax purposes, which I used as needed, but otherwise left those alone in Mint. In CreditKarma all those options are gone without a replacement.

I was forced to switch to ck from mint and am really disappointed that they think ck is similar enough. The ck interface is barely usable. They make it hard to get to actual information, but ads are front and center. What I miss the most about mint isn't even an option, which is the transactions widget. After using mint for many years, I guess I'll go back to manually tracking. Buyouts ruin every good app.

Moved from Mint. It's nice to have my accounts in one place but the ads are unbearable. I really only use this so I can continue budgeting via spreadsheet without having to open all of my accounts separately. On It's own, it's not an effective budgeting tool because the transaction categories aren't always right. I guess if you're shopping for new cards/loans you can go for it but at that point, you may as well look on Nerd Wallet or do your own research

Good app to keep track of your credit but never apply for a financial product from their app. They will constantly push more and more financial product like loans, refinancing, etc. through emails and notifs which is full of false and misleading advertising and vendors. You will end up with a hard inquiries on your credit report and the actual terms or the offer will nowhere be even remotely close to what they advertise. Even the ones that say "excellent approval odds". Had horrible experiences

The Mint app was killed and my account was rolled into this. I've used credit karma in the past for basic monitoring and CC recommendations, but the debt, asset and net worth tracking is far worse than Mint. Accounts don't update and you never have an accurate picture. In the time it takes to relink/ refresh all accounts, you could just check them all individually. No added utility which is the whole point...

Disgusting app. I opened an account to help boost my credit score, but when I could no longer keep the account active. They lowered my score more than what it could help. Guys stay far away from opening any accounts with credit karma. It won't help in the long run. It boosts your credit score up far too slow but then when you're done with wasting money on it because you have more important and better things to do with your money, it drops your score about 3-5 times lower than what it went up.
data.replyText: Hi, please note that Intuit Credit Karma is not a credit repair service, Credit Karma's provide's your score's and reports directly from TransUnion and Equifax in the Vantage 3.0. We depend on the bureaus to provide updates. Having a Credit Karma account has no direct impact to you.

data.text: Was forced to move from Mint to this and it's not nearly as good. Many of my accounts don't update for multiple days so everything is out of sync and inaccurate. It's much harder than Mint to get an overall view of everything in one place. I can't click into individual accounts to look at transactions. I haven't found a monthly budget to look at my categorized spending. And there are ads EVERYWHERE. I really loved Mint and used it constantly but I'm not sure I can get much use out of this.

I was forced to move my data over to Credit Karma when Intuit discontinued the Mint app (shame). Credit Karma is not a budgeting app in my opinion. The budgeting features are buried beneath a million credit card offers, info, and scores, true to it's name I guess. When I open this app, I feel like it's nothing but ads, promotions, and spam, instead of helpful insights and focus around managing your money better. I, along with many friends, are switching to alternative budgeting apps.

Forced to update due to Intuit discontinuing the Mint app, which I loved. In this app I can't even see transactions within my accounts, only the balance. I thought it would be an upgrade, but I feel I took 1 step fwd, and 2 steps back. Please give us access to transactions within each account like mint. The app seems to crowded selling things. I don't need a new credit card, a loan or insurance. I just want to see my accounts and details like I used to.

I hated to see all the work I put into budgeting with Mint go, so I reluctantly switched to credit karma. It isn't just that it's mostly ads and hard to get to anything you might want the app for. It's that you are being pushed to get more credit cards specifically, which undermines the purpose of a budgeting app. Very disappointing.

Inaccurate credit reporting. TransUnion and Equifax drop the score by 70 points or more when credit card balance is dropped by 50% or more .. or when credit cards are paid off. Also, they drop 12 points when there's a credit inquiry... rather than 2 points which has been the standard for years. When calling the customer service for either bureau to find out why they drop the score rather than increasing it, when payments are made on time and cards are paid off, they read off a script.
data.replyText: Please note that Intuit Credit Karma does not create this information as it comes directly from TransUnion and Equifax. Intuit Credit Karma has no direct impact on you as we do not report to outside sources. Your scores and reports are provided for informational purposes only.

data.text: Credit karma is great, but emailing customer support is terrible. At first, I would get fast responses, and after that, it would take a whole day to just get one response. Had to email 7 times because every answer I received is not even close to what I am asking for. When I finally got my answers, they partially answered it. Customers' support was not helpful at all. With that experience, I saved myself the headache into switching to another bank that fulfilled my needs.

Breakdown by Category: Sign up/transition: -3 (many hoops, deactivated email, painful and not straighforward solutions) Tracking Money: 2 (does everything Mint does but hides it on the 3rd page and behind ads) User friendliness: 2 (average, but the ads make it hard to navigate around) Budget options: unknown, thus 0 Moving between Intuit: 4 I liked Mint for what it was, and it seems like they are working that into the app still. It may grow on me over time.

I don't understand the point of this app. After using Mint for many years, this tool is seriously lacking in ANY sort of notable features. Why Intuit migrated us here instead of just moving Mint to a subscription service is beyond me. You'll be able to see your account balances here, see your net worth, see your credit score, and interact with almost none of it in any real way. No budgeting tools. But you WILL be able to see some nice credit card ads. I'll find a new tool instead.

I only started using this app bc Mint merged with it. I dislike the UI so much. Like you'd think the home page would link to see your transactions and accounts but no I have to go down a rabbit hole bc they are pushing ads for credit cards, loans, etc. I'm probably going to uninstall with the day. I gave it a shot for a month, but it is too clunky.

I loved Mint and used it for years. I liked using Credit Karma for checking credit scores and looking at card recommendations, but I hate that they got rid of Mint and did not deliver the merge I expected. This is not like Mint. Yes, you can see the credit card transactions that do link correctly, but you can no longer check bank account transactions nor budget. Really disappointing.

They purposely will not let you download transaction data. Only focus is on aggressively selling you products. Edit - There is nothing to help troubleshoot. The option to download transactions does not exist. Copy and pasting is limited to the visible screen only. That isn't an accidental web function. Credit Karma does not allow downloads of transaction data.
data.replyText: Sorry to hear that! Could you write to us at https://support.creditkarma.com/s/newcase with more details of your issue? We'd love to help you troubleshoot.

data.text: I don't need much in a personal budgeting app and I don't mind ads here and there to cover the cost of doing business, but I've never seen a finance app UI that was more confusing and provided me less insights than what I had prior. I'm going to miss Mint after having used it for over a decade but this app ain't it. I tried Credit Karma prior to the forced merger and it was a stark comparison so to think they would choose to migrate to the user experience that had less utility is baffling.

This is probably the worst app I've ever used in my entire life. What used to be a really good system (Mint) has been replaced by credit Karma. This app is loaded with ads and it's just one gigantic credit card promotion tool. It has lost all useful functionality to the user for managing personal finances viewing transactions etc. All of that useful functionality is now buried deep within the app under a myriad of dozens of pages of credit card, credit report, credit protection, etc. F-

I would give negative rating if there was an option! CK is pathetic when compared to Mint. 1. Ads are fine, but not to the extent that the entire app is flooded with it. 2. UX is horrible. The workflows are not simple/intuitive. It's so clouded that you barely get constructive info. 3. The accounts are not updated for days, I always see old data. 4. While I like the credit report related info, there should be an option of hiding debts pulled from credit report when tracking monthly budgeting

First off, I was forced to switch from Mint to this because of the company. This app is only good for selling you credit cards and monitoring your credit score. I guess net worth if the average person cares about that all, but I'm sure there are better things for that. This app is NOT for budgeting at all. Only an ignoramus would think this was actually a good stand-in for Mint. The UI is horrific. Again, this app is designed to sell you credit cards and, apparently, car insurance.

Good to know if you want a general idea what your credit score is but it fails in making a seamless experience because it is crowded with offers for loans, credit cards and pushing you to use their tax services. Sadly, Intuit killed Mint, so budgeting isn't here, though it shows some of the information, but the features for it are lacking. This app is a good download to check before making any financial moves like buying a car or house and the uninstalling to avoid the multiple ad notifications.

I switched over from mint. credit karma seems to be similar, but I haven't had the patience to wade through the ads. My spam email doubled after switching (all investment related). My bank app shows my credit score just as easily as this app, so I'm just going to go back to the old-school spreadsheet budgeting. I don't feel comfortable giving access to my bank account when they're selling my data.

Transitioned from Mint to this. This app is completely useless for budgeting. It has none of the features I was used to on Mint. This app is intended for a totally different purpose... to con people into talking out loans or opening lines of credit they probably don't need. It is more of a scam than it is useful for anything else. No bueno. I wish there was a less that 1 star rating.

Nice for credit scores, terrible for budgeting. Like everyone else reviewing this, I had a Mint account that was converted over to Credit Karma. Mint had a nice clean interface that made it easy to track and sort my expenses. Sure, it had a few issues and occasional ads, but they were easy to work around. Credit Karma, on the other hand, is completely bloated with ads and is no way meant to be used as a budgeting app. At this rate I'm just gonna go back to tracking my accounts with spreadsheets.

Used to love this app. Was great at breaking down my credit score and helping me understand what goals to set for myself. Things have changed so much and now all this app really does is push loans, credit cards, and insurance on you, it's hard to even find the small section that explains your credit score. It's NOT for credit monitoring as much as them just trying to make money off of you. Sad.

Credit Karma is so full of ads to the point that you don't want to use it. The entire focus is the ads and not your finances. Both the app and website lack basic functionality. Connected accounts do not refresh automatically. You have to tell it to refresh each account or it won't update daily. It's extremely hard to find basic functions between all the pages of ads. It's a hot mess. 0/5 stars.

I was using mint to track my finances across my bank and credit cards. It used to be really helpful, but I'd occasionally have to re log in to my stuff. Then I suddenly was getting messages that there were 3+ attempts to log into my bank account! Seemed fishy. Then the company says they were switching to this app, so I made the switch and now I have tons of ads for things I don't want, and I don't think this tracks spending the same way I was doing. Frustrating....

I don't know who's your UI guru but you should fire them. You have a serious scrolling issue in the Cards tab. Every time I scroll to go back to the top of the screen, the app instead tries to reload all my cards info (I see the loading icon) instead of simply scrolling back to top of the screen. The only workaround is to tap in a different tab and tap back again to the cards tab. I'm sure it's not rocket science and you should be able to fix it.
data.replyText: Thank you for taking the time provide us with your insight. We are always looking for ways to improve your experience as a member.

data.text: I really don't appreciate that we were all forced into this credit karma app. It's not even close to what mint was. Their main goal is just to advertise credit cards, insurance, and loans. You can't even manage your money on the app. I really wanted to keep all my finances together with Intuit because I trust them and I used to do my taxes with them but now there's just way better apps out there for my money.

AVOID THIS APP. This app is absolutely designed to prey on people with poor knowledge of credit and finances, as almost every screen has an ad for opening a new credit card or loan. It tries to decieve you into thinking that opening a large amount of credit cards (5!!) is acceptable. An absolutely abysmal replacement for Mint, and I jumped ship after the 20+ times it tried to advertise credit cards in less than 10 minutes.

I've tried them all at the same time and the process of eliminating left the best app, can't say enough at how well and easy to use this app is. The information they provide is so relevant and to the point. The offers are on the spot and and the overall it is the best. After spending a whole year on working all the different apps to determine the best on for me, This one wins hands down. Thank you Credit Karma

Forced to move from mint to CK. The pages on mint were easy to read and well organized. CK has done a poor job of taking over mints functions. The first page is overloaded with information I don't need on a daily basis and is used to advertise credit cards and car insurance I don't want. Mint had useful charts to make it easier to see where your money was going this feature has not been added. I used mint for quite a while and I am extremely disapponted in this move. Looking for a alternative.

Lots of noise from ads and offers to the point that it feels like that is focus of the app rather than the financial tools. I know free apps need revenue from advertising, but this is getting pretty out of hand. I also have gotten a login error and can't get into my account since transitioning from Mint... Hoping that goes away but would recommend waiting as long as you can since there is no way to revert.

Waste of time. Your information is only updated once a month or even longer. Credit score is inaccurate. For some reason my score never reaches 800, and I have no depth and always pay before my due date. Also I pay my current balance all the time. My credit score has been between 770 - 780 for the past 3 years, and my score does not go above that but goes down sometimes. Went to the dealer to purchase a car and my credit score that the dealer showed me is higher than the one that the app has
data.replyText: Lenders generally, only update the credit bureaus once a month which means it's normal for your report to be a full billing cycle behind current info. That being said, if your account has stopped updating, we want to help! You can reach our Member Support team here: https://bit.ly/2shuAx3

data.text: Lacks everything Mint had. Accounts do not track, ads to sign up for credit cards EVERYWHERE, and overall not pleasant to use. Wish I kept Mint as it was and did not switch. Mint had occasional hiccups like all apps but would sort itself quickly. It also allowed easy budgeting and tracking of expenses, even saving me from some issues. Would give zero stars if possible to Credit Karma.

Like many of the other people commenting, I started using Credit Karma when I was forced to migrate over from Mint (which I used for years) last year. This platform is terrible and borderline unusable. I gave CK the benefit of the doubt and continued to use it assuming it was just new and would eventually improve, but clearly that's not the case. Needless to say I will be deleting this app and moving to a platform that provides more than a "net worth" graph along with a bunch of credit card ads.

It's an ad bot. You'll get reminders that "Your credit score has changed." Just to click and find out there was no change, it was just click bait. It does a terrible job tracking accounts. I just got a congratulatory message for 100% on-time payments for a closed account. I clicked on the reminder and found out the last update from that account was early last year. It's truly just a worthless app that draws you in only to look at ads for credit cards and loans. Pathetic replacement for Mint.

Unistalled - I got screwed on my taxes through Credit Karma 2 or 3 years ago. I was able to get it corrected, so I kept the app so I could still look at my score and compare credit cards. I play a couple games that have ads. You have ads that open your app if I don't touch directly on the center of the X. I'm tired of the app opening up when I don't need it, so I'm uninstalling. I did the same thing with another app. This practice is extremely shady, and it shouldn't be acceptable or even legal.

Not great as a Mint alternative like they want it to be.. I used Mint to keep track of my spending. Yes, you can see some of that in this app, but it is primarily a bunch of advertisements for different credit card offers.. You have to scroll way off to the side and click through a few things to get to your accounts, and then it only shows one month of transactions. When you click "show all transactions," it means for all accounts, not just the one you're trying to look at. Disappointing.

If you want to see your credit score and get a lot of ads for credit cards the app/service does a pretty good job. However, if you are thinking this may help you with budgeting and tracking your spending it is absolute garbage. I used Mint for almost 10 years and it did a great job of tracking my spending, linking accounts, and helping w budgets. Mint was closed an Intuit request I move over to CK. The networth and spending tracking are vastly inferior to Mint. Intuit will lose many customers.

Not as good as Mint. It automatically picks up information off my credit report and does not allow me to unlink or hide this information, so I can't get it to display the balance that I am looking for. Budget breakdowns are also lacking - I am not able to see categorized expenses from previous months. It does do a good job with linking external accounts and tracking transactions.

This ck app is way worse than the outgoing mint app. Mint app seems to miss transactions lately and the quality degrades over time. But this ck app is a joke. Can't see all transactions for a specific card. I need to have multiple clicks to see things I used to have one click to go to. Can't see last 4 digits of cards, which is a big hassle as I have many cards. There's no sync option. It's a textbook lesson how a good business turns bad. Good riddance.

It doesn't meet the bar in tracking finances. There doesn't seem to be any rhyme/reason to when it pulls down transactions from linked credit cards or bank accounts. There can be more than a week lag before seeing a transaction, so your balance will be incorrect. Was used to seeing txns updated within hours when using Mint. Also, no details to investments, so you can't see when you make deposits. If it's not accurate, then why use it?

I was basically forced to switch to this APP from the MINT app. This new APP has tons of misc. junk that pushes loans, insurance, credit cards, etc. And does not show "bank" transactions, just the amount of money in the account. Therefore, you cannot budget or monitor the accounts very well. So annoying! The objective of this APP is clearly different than MINT. In my opinion, MINT is better!

As a many year Mint user, I was hesitant to switch over after Intuit sunset Mint. my concerns were valid and Credit Karma doesn't meet my needs. The focus of the app is on credit and credit cards and it is full of ads for CCs, car loans, car insurance, credit monitoring, etc. It is impossible to remove a card if it is part of your credit report, so net worth tracking is broken. Budgeting is trash. I might keep it just for credit monitoring but Monarch is meeting all of my needs now.

Recent changes have this app riddled with ads for credit cards or loans against a tax refund. If you are someone who is tempted by such ads, while attempting to repair your credit, stay away from this app. While your score is upfront in what you see, so are the ads that you have to scroll through to find any additional information - e.g. at the *bottom* of the intro page is your debt information after about a half a dozen ads. They've always been there, but are worse now.

Was forced to switch to this after using Mint for several years. This app doesn't track anything that I want it to. There are fewer charts that help visualize my spending habits, net worth, etc. The main thing it shows you is your credit score and tons of ads for loans and credit cards. If they don't make this app more like mint I will be deleting it. I have no use for it.

Awful, was forced to use this after they bought Mint. Doesn' let you add manual transactions. Accounts dont sync. Clunky, has 1 or 2 graphs, that's it. Inaccurate monthly & yearly spend. Doesn't have a budgeting tool. Basically , it's a place for ads to sell you more credit cards and loans; a big scam. Haven't found anything remotely close to Mint yet. In fact, I think Im going to unlink my accounts and just shut it down cause I'm sick of their notifications. Extremely disappointed

Not nearly as good as Mint was üôÅ. Harder to get info at a glance, the homepage it takes you to is all advertisements, then you have to go over to another page but every time you click into one kind of account it takes you to another page (with a lot more advertisements) instead of being able to see it all together. Also it doesn't show as much information per account.

Hate it compared to mint. This is a severe downgrade considering I had been using mint for 10 years. There is no data from my checking account except the total value (can't see if/when rent was taken out), the transactions are only visible by account not aggregated. It's been maybe a month since I switched and it's miserable. It might be great if you only want to see high level, but for someone more interested in more details this is not great.

Credit Karma is a weak shadow of what mint was. The UI is the worst thing I've ever seen for a finance app and I can hardly track anything besides my credit score without an "suggestion" for something being thrown in my face. Instead of just moving people's data the app should have been updated to reflect mints effective, user friendly budget tracking, tools, and assistances.

This app is terrible. Mint was a great product and Intuit killed it. Most of the tabs in Credit Karma are trying to sell you credit cards and other products. My accounts are not syncing properly. It is very difficult to navigate around in the app. The credit score info is not helpful compared to what other apps give you. Do not use this app.

Lacks everything good about Mint app. Tons and tons of ads covering everything. Credit card offers plastered everywhere. The information I want like Mint had is all over the place and layout is to show you more ads. The data from my accounts don't update in real time, especially loans lag even after payment is made. I have to manually add the value of a rental property (Mint allowed multiple properties). I wish I would have never switched and now I cannot go back.

Doesn't support variable assets like mint used to support. Severely annoyed it doesn't have as good or better support than the expiring resource. F- from a product parity perspective. It feels like a greasy way to inject useless ads in my life I never needed. The dashboards are absolutely useless and it's frustrating trying to pull any data or reporting out. I absolutely hate what Intuit has done.

I already miss the mint app. I moved my data over, and it's a so much worse user experience on ck. My accounts aren't refreshing unless I manually hit the refresh button in settings, I can't look at transactions per account, there's no home screen widget for my balances & there's no budget section. I'm hoping there's another app out there like mint.

Basically it is a tool to sell you financial services. It's disguised as an account management app but it is a poor substitute for Mint. It's clunky to maneuver. Offers poor historical data and is generally a huge step backwards. I'm not sure I'll continue to use it. I'm most interested in budgeting and tracking my spending in various categories. That was easy to do in Quicken and later the Mint app. Credit Karma is NOT useful for that. It is a poor substitute for both Quicken and Mint. D

This app is bs. I filed with turbo tax like always, and they have added this new feature that I did not want to sign up for. My debit card never came. I have talked to customer support numerous times, and they have not been any help. It won't allow me to link my bank account, so in order to transfer money, it charges 1.75% of the amt. It won't let me set up the virtual card, so if I need to pay for anything, I have to use the routing and acct number.
data.replyText: Hi, we're sorry to hear that and we would love to take a look at the issue. Please provide us with your case number so that we may further assist you.

data.text: NON EXISTING CUSTOMER SERVICE! They decided to randomly close my account for the reason of "violating their policies" and there is nothing that Violated. I barely use it abs my transactions are between me and family/friends all under $100. I've called 3 times, it's been 2 months, no reply, no response on reopening my account but that I just have to wait because it's still under review. It's takes 2 months to review a simple account that barely makes 4 transactions a month??? No ANSWER!

The app itself is worthwhile, but they are constantly offering loans and credit cards that, if i accepted, would make my credit history even worse. But, my biggest complaint is the ads they place in my games. No matter what I select they are constantly taking me to the app screen to download it, when I already have it! And, it takes a minimum of 3 attempts to actually clear their ad and get back to my game.

Just really unhelpful compared to mint... I could have kept using mint for many years and had been for some time, now I feel forced into a totally different and lesser experience. To be more specific, I miss easily being able to see things like graphs and charts of my spending categories and swipe between months. It was also easy to search for transactions in mint and to create budgets. CK just looks worse and functions worse overall & feels like it only wants to sell me something.

Horrible bait and switch for Mint users, this app has far fewer features than Mint, and once switched over, we don't have the ability to go back. Intuit is closing mint for good in March so I figured I'd get started on it, but it's so awful. You can't search your transactions, just scroll thru them. It only allows you to connect one property with a loan, to keep track of your net value on it, and sets your property values ridic high (can't override) & vehicle values are much lower than in mint.

I was forced on to this app because Mint went away. It was supposed to replace mint, but it doesn't have nearly as much functionality (I can't even see half of my transactions! What's the point! ) and I'm honestly just mad that I even imported my info into credit karma at all. It has tons of ads everywhere and just feels cheap. Very displeased. I miss mint.

Had mint and had to convert to this. Good for basic monthly tracking. Cannot split transactions. Cannot view past spending details, only current month spending details and overall historical past spend. Horrible for budgeting which is/was my primary reason for having had mint for YEARS. In search of a new app. Sad to lose mint and all my historical data...

I miss Mint. Credit Karma is always a day or so out of date with data, I can't find anywhere to refresh my accounts, and it's made it so instead of having everything in one place, I have to go into my individual apps to see my balances. The credit rating snapshot is nice, but I used Mint to monitor my balances in one place at any time and it was live data. This app fails for that. Also, somehow it's set to a state I haven't lived in for 13 years and NO place I can change it.

I've tried to click through the credit karma ad on my game 1000 times. I already have the app but how difficult you make it to click onto the game is SUPER ANNOYING. Anyone who has any amount of coding experience knows it's purposeful. Literally makes me want to delete the app. The other ads aren't nearly as obnoxious.

I absolutely hate this app. I cannot believe I am forced to use it over Mint. It is not intuitive. 95% of this app is just trying to force new loans or credit cards down your throat and I can never find what I'm looking for, which are my transactions and checking my budget. I would much rather Mint had stayed intact than Intuit forcing us to use this version.

This is absolute trash compared to Mint. It doesn't have any of the same budgeting features, and all it tries to do is to get you to sign up for credit cards and loans. My info didn't accurately transfer over and was a pain because I had an old, outdated neglected account with credit karma. All of my old transaction history was lost, which I needed. They shouldn't have tried to fix something that wasn't broken.

Migrated from Mint. Mint was a great service on its own, with a great widget, and features. Credit karma was ok to get a glance at your credit scores. But then credit karma became greedy and forced ads, credit card/loan sign ups in your face. Now that Mint was moved into Credit Karma we've lost the widget features, and lost helpful budgeting breakdown tools, and I get ads constantly while trying to budget. Ruined 2 great apps due to greed.

I'm really disappointed with this app and will be searching for a different one to budget and track my finances all in one place. Mint worked great and was very helpful, and I migrated my accounts over to credit karma as suggested since mint is shutting down, and I assumed the experience would be the same or better, but it's not. This credit karma app is not useful at all. I can't click on individual accounts to see transactions, no budgeting info, and it doesn't update in realtime

As the "successor" to Mint, an app I used for well over a decade, Credit Karma falls remarkably flat. The app is basically a vehicle for financial service-related advertisements and then if you happen to click the right things, you'll get some of the finance tracking features Mint offered. I already find myself using it significantly less and will find a different option soon. If you're looking for financial tracking this is not the app you're looking for.

The way they show you which credit cards you're likely to get approved for and how you can so easily check your credit score at any time- these things are national treasures, in my opinion. You can avoid being rejected and also see what you need to do to raise your credit score. You might even be able to skip the prepaid card! My score has gone from 650 to 800! And I have been saving money by taking advantage of rewards. This feels so much better than payday loans. I've moved up!

Please do not participate in the credit builder program. Again, PLEASE DO NOT! You are committed once you join, or your credit will suffer as a result. The biggest reason is it doesn't work!!! ü§® over a year using app. I contacted customer service, and they did not follow through on their commitment to contact me. Issues are only resolved by email, and they never email. Everything else with app is ok.
data.replyText: Oh no! We sincerely apologize for the troubles you've had with the app. We'd be happy to take a look into this for you, please contact us at https://support.creditkarma.com/s/newcase. Thank you.

data.text: The forced move from mint sucks. It does not have nearly any of the budgeting features that mint had. The credit monitoring features are decent, but I prefered using mint for my budgeting. All this one does is track your transactions theres no way to catagorize or put in monthly bills. I dont understand why they even integrated the two apps. Also once you do, you cant see anything in your mint app at all, ever again. So thats nice üôÑ

Absolute trash. I used to use credit karma for my credit score. I will never use it again after what they did with mint. It makes you link all of your credit accounts then doesn't update them for weeks. Mint would refresh your card balance every time you opened it. It's not your credit score relying on the bureaus, it has direct access to your accounts SO WHY DOESN'T IT UPDATE. Will never use turbo tax, tsheets or anything Intuit again.

Was forced to move from Mint. Net worth calculation in CK is useless since your loan balances are pulled from your credit report instead of your account. Your payment is deducted from cash assets when you pay but it doesn't appear that the loan was paid for 30 days or longer (in my case it hasn't updated since the end of last year, almost 2 months ago). Thus if you have a loan your net worth calculation is never accurate. Intuit had two redundant apps and killed the wrong one.

The only reason I'm even giving this app a three is because currently it's the only one that connects with my credit union. When mint closed and forced me to Credit Karma I kept my fingers crossed for a good experience. Unfortunately if you are actually trying to keep track of your spending and accounts this app is terrible. You can't easily look at what's going on in each account. It does not update the accounts regularly and it's way too many clicks to do it manually. Barely 3 stars.

A platform for ads. Mint was the greatest and making users move to this was an epic mistake. I used CK before just to check my credit, but any other use of it was buried in ads for other products and messy navigation. So much of the functionality of Mint is not there in CK and what little there is, is so stupid hard to find among the ads. Gonna close my CK account over this. I can check my credit through any credit card. I'm fact, Intuit loses my business on TurboTax too.

Transfered from the Mint app to track finances and spending. (Which was mandatory). This is a massively worse and less feature complete platform. Cannot filter and see as many individual line charts the way you could in mint, (spending, investments, net worth, etc) and accounts say they were last updated 2 days ago with no clear way how to update/refresh them. Plus it's mixed in with a lot of other stuff I don't care for/need vs. doing the one thing I actually use it for really well.

Pretty good app. A few things could be better. For example, if I'm putting in the wrong email, don't give an error message stating: "We can't contact Credit Karma at this time." This implies it's down for maintenance or something. Also, selecting another way to sign in straight up did not work, and I had to sign in with my password anyway. The latest update has moved the app around in a worse way. Why can't I see my balance when I first open it anymore?
data.replyText: Oh no! We sincerely apologize for the troubles you've had with the app. We'd be happy to take a look into this for you, please contact us at https://support.creditkarma.com/s/newcase. Thank you.

data.text: I switched because they bought Mint. So far I hate the credit karma app. It's slow, clunky, not user friendly for managing my finances. It's great at credit reporting, which I maintained a separate account with them for that reason. But their financial management app is actually making it harder to track my finances because accounts don't connect, they don't update, they never load, it's useless and I miss Mint. And there's SO many ads. I do not want more credit cards! Leave me alone!

Forced to this app from mint. I haven't found a more useless app than this one. Nothing is easy to find. It just seems to advertise loans and credit cards. After moving from mint... It does not sync correctly... Nothing intuitive about this app. Also There are far better apps for monitoring credit scores. Intuit really failed me on this one. A complete lack of understanding of how people use their apps. After this I will be considering alternative tax products as well.

Stuck using this site to Mint shutting down. I'm very disappointed. No budgeting tools or a way to see my bank and credit accounts. All this thing does is sell you loans and credit cards. It doesn't even update accounts to show your balances, debt, and net worth accurately. I'm deleting all my accounts and finding something else. Such a bummer.

Forced to transition from Mint with worse spend tracking and budgeting features. No longer picks up income from my bank. 90% of the app is credit card and loan ads. It automatically added my home loan, and i only want to track spending. I'll likely look for an alternative. Missing features I've noticed so far: *Can't review expenses by month *Automatic budgeting not available *Vendor search/summary And please add dark mode.

UI is a mess. Buggy - numbers not matching up between tabs, accounts un-linking, weird glitches when trying to add property. 80% of the dashboard is an advertisement to get you to open up new credit cards and loans. Just feels like a super gross data mining scheme. Looking for a replacement ASAP as the Mint app I once loved is long gone.

Update: Even the response is inadequate. After being with them for years, they made it impossible to update my phone number, insisting I send a photo of my dl to verify myself. The final straw was sitting and waiting for over an hour, 3X'S, in virtual assistant, only to be disconnected without answers. Only downloaded the app to leave the review! Will be looking for alternatives.
data.replyText: We apologize for the difficulties you experienced while registering with us. If you would like some assistance or additional information, please contact us via https://support.creditkarma.com/s/newcase and we will be happy to help you further.

data.text: This app has the potential to be great, but it's being held back by the fact that net worth barley updates your information, leaving all your balances outdated. I had some bank accounts and credit cards going 3 or 4 days without updating, sometimes more. This is frustrating because Mint used to refresh every time you opened the app, or at least every day. Very disappointed with transitioning to this app because of this. They use credit bureaus instead of directly updating, which is much worse.
data.replyText: Hi please note that the information you see on Credit Karma is not created or updated by Credit Karma. We depend on the bureaus to provide updates to this information.

data.text: This app is much worse than the Mint Intuit app. Unfortunately it forced me to close the last app and move onto this one. Before I could easily view everything from a single dashboard, but now I have to click through each tab. And it takes forever to load. There's a bunch of missing and valuable information that the previous app had. May completely uninstall altogether and find something else.

Since mint merged with credit karma, i was expecting the same features to be on credit karma. Hardly half of the features are there. The overview looks busy, no goals, no budget, hard to see each acxounts balance at a glance, harder to keep track of spending. Intuit is obviously going down hill, and must have some bad leadership. Trash taste all around. Used mint for years, expected an upgrade, instead lost all the good features.

this is a piss poor replacement for Mint. This app, as best I can tell, is an electronic billboard for selling financial services from any vendor paying Intuit for ad space. With web browser mint I could do year over year quarter over quarter analysis. It's now about a month later and it STILL SUCKS! Mint allowed users to analyze spending. CK pushes credit card offers, and lets credit companies know your financial information...that's it! I tried it, canceled it. I never had these issues w/Mint

The interface was perfect for years and years, it was a 10/10. Then recently, they completely changed it all around and made it more cluttered and complex. Now I hate it. And I can't change the time-span on my charts anymore. Whoever made all these dumb, unnecessary changes to the interface should be fired. It was perfect before.
data.replyText: Hi, we are always looking to improve the experience for our users, and really appreciate the feedback. If you have any further feedback you would like to share please contact us at https://support.creditkarma.com/s/newcase.

data.text: This app sux!! I used Mint for years to track bills and remind me when payments are due. Then I was forced to "move all my accounts" to CK, but that's bullcrap. My accounts are not there and if I want to track my bills I have to create a Money Spending account through CK. Eff that shite! I just want a simple way to track my bills. Now I'm back at square one. Really disappointed that Mint is no longer an option. It wasn't perfect but at least it fulfilled my basic needs.
